title: Winter wellness simplified: How to consume dry fruits - The Financial Express
Doctors stress on a healthy diet to fight winter ailments - The Times of India
summary:
Doctors Stress on a Healthy Diet to Fight Winter Ailments

Publication Date: Not specified, Source: Times of India

As winter approaches, doctors emphasize the importance of maintaining a healthy diet to prevent seasonal ailments such as flu and cold. Proper nutrition is essential for bolstering immunity and overall health during the colder months.

  • Increased consumption of fruits and vegetables is recommended.
  • Hydration remains crucial even in winter, with herbal teas being a good choice.
  • High-protein foods can aid in muscle maintenance during a sedentary season.
  • Maintaining a balanced diet helps in preventing common winter illnesses.
Health experts state, "A strong immune system is built on consistent nutrition and hydration, especially in the winter months."

In conclusion, a proactive approach to diet can significantly enhance health and wellness during winter, reducing the risk of seasonal diseases.
newTitle: Doctors Stress on a Healthy Diet to Fight Winter Ailments

title: Couch potatoes beware! Sitting too much may lead to 19 serious health problems - The Times of India
summary:
Couch potatoes beware! Sitting too much may lead to 19 serious health problems

Publication Date: N/A Source: N/A

Sitting for prolonged periods can lead to numerous health issues, asserting the importance of incorporating movement into daily routines.

  • Increased risk of heart disease
  • Higher likelihood of diabetes
  • Potential for weight gain
  • Impact on mental health
  • Development of musculoskeletal problems
  • Link to certain types of cancer
  • Reduced life expectancy
  • Negative effects on metabolic rate
  • Impaired circulation
  • Increased risk of anxiety and depression
"A sedentary lifestyle can be as harmful as smoking."

In conclusion, addressing the risks of a sedentary lifestyle is crucial for health and wellbeing, encouraging individuals to integrate more movement into their daily lives.

title: US Surgeon General urges cancer warnings for alcoholic drinks - The Tribune India
summary:
US Surgeon General urges cancer warnings for alcoholic drinks

Publication Date: Friday, Date Unspecified - Source: The Tribune

In a significant health advisory, US Surgeon General Vivek Murthy is urging that all alcoholic drinks carry a warning about the associated cancer risks, highlighting the increased likelihood of at least seven types of cancer linked to alcohol consumption.

  • Alcohol consumption is linked to cancer types including breast, colon, and liver cancer.
  • Surgeon General calls for reassessment of alcohol consumption guidelines.
  • Alcohol is the third leading preventable cause of cancer in the US, after tobacco and obesity.
  • Shares in alcohol companies have fallen following the announcement.
  • Current health warnings are minimal and have not changed since 1988.
  • Congress will ultimately decide on the implementation of new labeling.
  • The report states alcohol causes around 100,000 cancer cases and 20,000 cancer deaths in the US annually.
“Warning labels won’t be an immediate deathblow to alcohol makers, but it will compound the long-term threats to the industry.” - Blake Droesch, analyst with eMarketer

This advisory may signal a shift in how alcoholic beverages are regulated, drawing parallels to early tobacco regulation efforts. The Surgeon General's recommendations highlight the importance of public awareness regarding the risks associated with alcohol consumption.
newTitle: US Surgeon General Calls for Cancer Warnings on Alcohol Labels

5 types of diet trends to lose weight and stay healthy - India.com
summary:
5 Types of Diet Trends to Lose Weight and Stay Healthy

Published on: January 4, 2025 by India.com

The article discusses various diet trends that have emerged in 2024, focusing on their potential impact on health and weight loss.

Key Points:

  • Mediterranean Diet: Emphasizes whole foods with heart-health benefits.
  • Intermittent Fasting: Involves alternating eating and fasting periods, aiding weight loss.
  • Plant-Based Diets: Focus on whole, plant-derived foods to improve health and weight.
  • Anti-Inflammatory Diet: Gained popularity after celebrity endorsement, targets inflammation reduction.
  • DASH Diet: Aims to combat high blood pressure while promoting balanced nutrition.

It's important to choose a diet that fits your lifestyle for effective weight management, and professional guidance is advised for significant dietary changes.

title: Why public health nutrition policies need novelty, precise targeting - The Hindu
summary:
Why public health nutrition policies need novelty, precise targeting

Date: January 04, 2025 Source: The Lancet

This article discusses the slow progress toward achieving Global Nutrition Targets (GNTs) for maternal and child nutrition, emphasizing the need for innovative approaches and precise targeting to address both undernutrition and overnutrition.

  • Global Nutrition Targets aim to alleviate maternal and child malnutrition, with specific goals for stunting, anaemia, and overweight.
  • A recent evaluation indicated insufficient progress in 204 countries from 2012 to 2021, projecting few nations will meet the targets by 2030.
  • Key reasons for slow progress include poor program implementation and inadequate understanding of anaemia causes in India.
  • Children are at risk of metabolic overnutrition, emphasizing the need for dual focus on both undernutrition and overnutrition.
  • Current policies need to diversify dietary approaches rather than solely focusing on specific nutrients.
"The need of the hour is to zealously and precisely focus on double duty actions to simultaneously address the under- and over-nutrition burden."

In conclusion, the effectiveness of public health nutrition policies requires a novel approach that considers the complexities of nutrition, addressing both deficiencies and excesses to foster healthier outcomes for future generations.
newTitle: Why public health nutrition policies need novelty, precise targeting

title: 10 superfoods to make your legs stronger - The Times of India
summary:
10 Superfoods to Make Your Legs Stronger

“You can supercharge your leg strength with some delicious, nutrient-packed foods!”

In conclusion, incorporating these superfoods into your diet can significantly improve leg strength and overall performance.

title: Study traces the route of Ebola virus to the skin surface - The Hindu
summary:
Study Traces Ebola Virus Transmission to Skin Surface

Date: January 04, 2025 Source: Science Advances

This study reveals a cellular route through which the Ebola virus can reach the skin surface, suggesting a potential method of person-to-person transmission from infected individuals.

  • Researchers traced how the Ebola virus traverses skin layers to reach the surface.
  • The study identified new cell types within the skin that the virus targets during infection.
  • This research indicates that human skin specimens can actively support Ebola virus infection.
  • Virus replication is more robust in the epidermal layer than in the dermal layer.
  • The infectious virus can be detected on the skin’s surface within three days.
The results suggest that the skin’s surface may be one route of person-to-person transmission.

This groundbreaking research enhances our understanding of Ebola virus transmission and highlights the skin as a critical area for further investigation.
newTitle: Study Traces Ebola Virus Transmission to Skin Surface

title: Even before US alcohol warning, younger Americans were turning to mocktails - Deccan Herald
summary:
Younger Americans Embrace Mocktails Amid Alcohol Cancer Warnings

Published: 04 January 2025, 16:20 IST

The US Surgeon General's alcohol warning may resonate with younger Americans, who have already been steering towards mocktails and juices in recent years.

  • In 2023, 49.6% of Americans aged 18-25 reported alcohol use in the past month, down from 59.6% in 2013.
  • Public health organizations are increasingly focusing on the risks of alcohol consumption.
  • Many consumers are opting for healthier, non-alcoholic beverage alternatives.
  • Experts assert that awareness campaigns will be necessary to connect alcohol consumption with cancer risks.
"It took massive public awareness campaigns to link cigarettes and lung cancer firmly in people's minds." - Sara Martin

The trend away from alcoholic beverages indicates a potential cultural shift among younger generations, suggesting they may prioritize health and wellness over traditional drinking norms.
newTitle: Younger Americans Embrace Mocktails Amid Alcohol Cancer Warnings

title: ‘India well-prepared’: On HMPV, govt says situation in China is not unusual - Hindustan Times
summary:
India's Preparedness Against Rising Respiratory Illnesses Amid China's HMPV Cases

Date: Jan 04, 2025

Source: Hindustan Times

The Union health ministry reassures the public that India is well-prepared to handle respiratory infections as reports of HMPV cases in China rise. The ministry describes the situation as not unusual.

  • A Joint Monitoring Group meeting was held to assess the rising respiratory illness cases.
  • Experts from WHO, IDSP, and other organizations participated in the deliberations.
  • The ministry attributes the surge to seasonal pathogens such as Influenza virus, RSV, and HMPV.
  • No significant increase in Influenza Like Illness (ILI) or Severe Acute Respiratory Illness (SARI) cases in India.
  • ICMR will enhance testing for HMPV and monitor trends throughout the year.
  • Health systems are described as vigilant and prepared for any health challenges.
"There is nothing to be alarmed about in the present situation." - Dr. Atul Goel, DGHS

In summary, India's health infrastructure is well-equipped to manage any respiratory illness increases, ensuring public health safety during the flu season.
newTitle: India's Preparedness Against Rising Respiratory Illnesses Amid China's HMPV Cases

title: Is moderate drinking safe? New study reveals the hidden dangers of alcohol consumption - Hindustan Times
summary:
Research debunks moderate drinking benefits; Surgeon General calls for updated health warnings on alcohol-related cancer risks.

Date: Jan 04, 2025 | Source: AP

With the new year comes Dry January and a new surgeon general's advisory on alcohol and cancer risk. Moderate drinking was once thought to have benefits for the heart, but recent research suggests otherwise.

  • U.S. Surgeon General Dr. Vivek Murthy urges updated health warnings on alcohol to include cancer risks.
  • Drinking alcohol increases the risk of several cancers, including colon, liver, breast, and throat.
  • The connection between moderate drinking and health benefits is challenged by recent studies.
  • New guidelines globally trend towards reduced alcohol consumption recommendations.
“Less is better when it comes to cancer risk,” said Dr. Vivek Murthy.

The evidence continues to mount against the benefits of moderate drinking, signaling a need for public health policy changes regarding alcohol consumption.
newTitle: New Study Questions Safety of Moderate Drinking and Urges Updated Cancer Warnings

summary:

title: HMPV in China: Is human metapneumovirus similar to Covid-19? What you need to know - The Economic Times
Norovirus Cases Surge In the US: Know The Symptoms Causes And How To Protect Yourself - TheHealthSite
summary:
Norovirus Cases Surge In the US: Know The Symptoms, Causes, And How To Protect Yourself

Publication Date: December 2025

Source: The Health Site

The CDC has reported a significant rise in norovirus cases in the US, with the week of December 5 showing 91 reported cases, which is over double the previous high from 2021 to 2024.

Key Points

  • Norovirus leads to gastroenteritis and symptoms appear 12-48 hours post-exposure.
  • Main symptoms include nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, and dehydration.
  • Causes of norovirus include contaminated food/water and person-to-person contact.
  • Special attention is needed for vulnerable groups like young children and older adults.
“This outbreak follows a statement from the Minnesota Department of Health, indicating twice the average stomach flu cases this December.”

In conclusion, awareness of norovirus symptoms and preventive measures is crucial given the current surge in cases.
newTitle: Norovirus Cases Surge In the US: Know The Symptoms, Causes, And How To Protect Yourself

title: HMPV outbreak in China: Telangana govt issues dos and don'ts — check details here | Today News - Mint
summary:
HMPV Outbreak in China: Telangana Government Issues Guidelines

Publication Date: Saturday

Source: Live Mint

The Telangana state government has issued a set of precautionary measures amid rising concerns over an HMPV outbreak in China, although no cases have been reported in Telangana.

Key Points

  • The Telangana health department reported no significant increase in respiratory infections compared to the previous year.
  • Dr. Atul Goyal advised general precautions and noted the lack of alarm.
  • Common symptoms of HMPV include cough, fever, nasal congestion, and shortness of breath.
  • The government issued specific do's and don'ts for citizens to follow.

Do’s

  • Cover your mouth and nose when coughing or sneezing.
  • Wash hands regularly with soap or sanitizer.
  • Avoid crowded places and maintain distance from sick individuals.
  • Stay home if feeling unwell.
  • Stay hydrated and consume nutritious food.

Don’ts

  • Do not reuse tissues or handkerchiefs.
  • Avoid close contact with sick individuals.
  • Steer clear of touching your face frequently.
  • Do not spit in public areas.
  • Avoid self-medication without professional advice.
“We are monitoring the situation in China. If an outbreak is detected that has the potential to spread to other areas, we can check its spread very quickly,” said Kerala Health Minister Veena George.
newTitle: HMPV Outbreak in China: Telangana Government Issues Guidelines

title: Throw away that cigarette, increase life expectancy: new study underlines benefits of smoking cessation - The Hindu
summary:
Throw Away That Cigarette, Increase Life Expectancy: New Study Highlights Benefits of Smoking Cessation

Publication Date: January 04, 2025 Source: The Hindu

The article discusses a new study from University College London that reveals the severe impacts of smoking on life expectancy, indicating that quitting smoking can significantly enhance overall health and longevity.

  • One cigarette may reduce life expectancy by 20 minutes.
  • Smoking is linked to five of the top ten global causes of death.
  • In India, 38% of men and nearly 9% of women over 15 use tobacco.
  • Smokers lose healthy years equivalent to their total years of life.
  • Immediate health benefits are observed upon quitting, such as reduced blood pressure and improved taste and smell.
  • Smoking cessation can prevent significant loss of life over time.
“Generally, a smoker will have other co-morbid conditions. Also, their ability to tolerate treatment, and their ability to complete planned treatment may be compromised.” - Arvind Krishnamurthy

The study emphasizes the urgent need for smoking cessation to improve public health outcomes and longevity, highlighting that the benefits begin almost immediately and can lead to significantly longer and healthier lives.
newTitle: Throw Away That Cigarette, Increase Life Expectancy: New Study Highlights Benefits of Smoking Cessation

title: No need to worry over reports of China flu outbreak: Kerala health minister - Business Standard
summary:
No need to worry over reports of China flu outbreak: Kerala health minister

Date: Jan 04 2025 | Source: Press Trust of India, Thiruvananthapuram

Kerala Health Minister Veena George addresses concerns regarding the outbreak of viral infections in China, assuring that there is no need for public panic as they monitor the situation closely.

  • George stated there have been no reports of a pandemic-causing virus from China.
  • Extra caution is advised for vulnerable groups like pregnant women, children, and the elderly.
  • The National Centre for Disease Control is monitoring the situation and coordinating with international agencies.
  • Health officials describe the Human Metapneumovirus as comparable to common respiratory viruses.
"We are monitoring the situation in China. If an outbreak is detected that has the potential to spread to other areas, we can check its spread very quickly." - Veena George

The Kerala government is taking preventive measures and remains vigilant in response to reports from China, emphasizing the importance of awareness and health safety.
newTitle: No Need to Panic Over China Flu Reports: Kerala Health Minister

title: ‘We are monitoring situation in China’: Kerala health minister on HMPV fears - The Indian Express
summary:
‘We are monitoring situation in China’: Kerala health minister on HMPV fears

Date: Recent news from Kerala

Source: The Indian Express

Kerala Health Minister Veena George addressed concerns regarding an outbreak of Human Metapneumovirus (HMPV) in China, assuring the public that the situation is being closely monitored without cause for panic. She recommended that sick children stay home and advised masks for vulnerable populations.

  • The state is monitoring respiratory diseases, especially among children and the elderly.
  • Travelers from abroad, particularly China, will be monitored for respiratory symptoms.
  • The first Covid-19 case in India was reported in Kerala.
  • HMPV has been present globally, including Kerala, for over 50 years.
  • Local labs are equipped to detect HMPV and its potential strains.
“Those with respiratory symptoms should use masks. There is no reason to panic. We are monitoring the situation in China,” said the minister.

Overall, while the outbreak poses concerns, the health ministry is prepared and stresses that public health measures are in place.
newTitle: Kerala Health Minister Monitors HMPV Situation Amid Concerns from China

In today's fast-paced world, prolonged sedentary activities contribute significantly to various chronic health conditions, including cardiovascular disease and diabetes.   • Sedentary lifestyles are linked to numerous health risks, including obesity and depression.
  • The American College of Sports Medicine introduced initiatives to integrate physical activity assessments into routine healthcare.

  • The Exercise Vital Sign (EVS) survey is proposed as a valuable tool for routine health screenings.

title: 6 healthiest reasons to drink haldi shot every morning - The Times of India
summary:
6 Healthiest Reasons to Drink Haldi Shot Every Morning

Publication Date: Unknown | Source: Unknown

Turmeric is a potent spice known for its medicinal properties, primarily due to its active ingredient, curcumin. Consuming a haldi shot every morning can maximize its health benefits.

  • Fight inflammation: Curcumin can combat chronic inflammation, which is linked to various diseases.
  • May possess anti-cancer abilities: Some studies suggest curcumin may inhibit cancer cell growth.
  • Helps in arthritis and joint pain: Curcumin shows promise in reducing joint pain compared to NSAIDs.
  • Improves bowel motions: Haldi shots may enhance digestion and metabolism, promoting weight loss.
  • Helps in improving memory: Curcumin seems to increase BDNF levels, benefiting memory and learning.
  • Blood purifier: Turmeric acts as a natural blood purifier with antioxidant properties.
“When Asha Parekh revealed the reason behind quitting Bollywood: 'The hero would come at 6:30 pm for a 9:30 am shift'”

Incorporating haldi shots into your routine can offer multiple health benefits, making it a valuable addition to your morning regimen.

title: US Surgeon General bats for cancer warnings on alcohol: Here's how it causes breast cancer - CNBCTV18
summary:
US Surgeon General Calls for Warning Labels on Alcohol Due to Cancer Risks

Publication Date: Friday | Source: CNBC

US Surgeon General Dr. Vivek Murthy has issued an advisory labeling alcohol as a leading preventable cause of cancer and recommending warning labels on alcoholic beverages.

Dr. Murthy highlighted that alcohol is responsible for approximately 100,000 cancer cases and 20,000 deaths annually in the US, exceeding fatalities from alcohol-related traffic incidents. He noted that alcohol is the third leading preventable cancer cause after tobacco and obesity.

  • Alcohol consumption is linked to breast cancer and is a significant modifiable risk factor.
  • The WHO reported that breast cancer diagnoses are escalating, with 1,579 cases daily in their European region.
  • In 2020, alcohol contributed to nearly 40,000 new breast cancer cases in the WHO European Region.
  • Dr. Marilys Corbex emphasized the need for public awareness regarding alcohol's role in breast cancer.
“Many people, including women, are not aware that breast cancer is the most common cancer caused by alcohol among women globally. By reducing alcohol consumption, they can reduce their risk of getting cancer.” – Dr. Marilys Corbex

WHO has classified alcohol as a Group 1 human carcinogen, linked to several cancers, and advises that there is no safe level of consumption.

The Surgeon General's proposal may face legislative hurdles amid opposition from the alcohol industry.
newTitle: US Surgeon General Calls for Warning Labels on Alcohol Due to Cancer Risks
